paragraphs: "Seal it," you tell the Editor. "No more new stories. No more crossings. What exists is enough."
The Editor's expression—if they have one—grows thoughtful. "Safety through stasis. The Understage becomes a museum. Every story exactly as it was meant to be, forever."
"Some stories are worth preserving exactly as they are."
"And some," the Editor counters softly, "deserve to grow."
You do not waver. "Growth brings chaos. The Understage has seen enough chaos."
A slow nod. The Editor accepts your choice.

The Mainstage transforms. The crystalline floor solidifies into unbreakable glass. The endless rigging locks into place. The curtains seal shut, becoming walls. The Understage becomes a vault—a closed canon, complete and unchanging.
Every story that exists continues to exist. Characters live their narratives in endless repetition, perfect performances of beloved tales. No new story will ever threaten what has been written.
The boundary between fiction and reality becomes absolute. No character will ever cross again. No breach will ever open.
It is safe. It is peaceful.

As the final seal sets, you feel a quiet melancholy. You have saved the Understage from chaos. You have also condemned it to repetition. Every story told exactly as written, forever, without surprise, without change, without growth.
Perhaps that is enough. Perhaps it must be.
